cab.content: IS DOCUMENT IS-THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT) .f$C RET.CABINET 25 (29).Copy No,CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the Cabinet heldin the Prime Minister s Room, House ofCommons, on WEDNESDAY, 26th June, 1929,at 3.0 p.m.PRESENTThe Right Hon. J. Ramsay MacDonald, M.P.,Prime Minister. (In the Chair).he Right Hon.I Philip Snowden, M.P.,Chancellor of the Exchequer.)iae Right Hon.J. H. Thoma s, M.P., Lordirivy Seal.pe Right Hon.lord Parmoor of Frieth, K.CV.0,K.C., Lord President of theCouncil.pe Right Hon.I, Wedgwood Benn, D.S .0,,I.F.C.,M.P., Secretary oflltate for India.The Right Hon.Arthur Henderson, M.P.,Secretary of State forForeign Affairs.The Right Hon.Lord Passfield, Secretaryof State for Dominions andthe Colonies.The Right Hon.J.R. Clynes, M.P., Secretaryof State for Home Affairs.The Right Hon.Tom Shaw, O.B.E., M.P.,Secretary of State for War.Eg.-General The Right Hon.Lord Thomson, C .B.E.,D.S.0. ,Secretary of State for Air.le Right Hon.Margaret Bondfield, M.P.,jpinister of Labour.The Right Hon.Sir Charles Trevelyan, M.P.,[ll?resident, Board of Education.The Right Hon.lj .V. Alexander, M.P., Firsttord of the Admiralty.The Right Hon.Arthur Greenv?ood, M.P.,Minister of Health.The Right Hon.Noel Buxton, M.P., Ministerof Agriculture and fisheries the Right Hon.William Graham, M.P.,President of the Board ofTrade.The Right Hon.William Adawson, M.P.,Secretary of State forScotland.The Right Hon.George Lansbury, M.P.,First Commissioner of Works.....sir M.P.A. Hankey, G.C.B. ,G.C.M.G........................ Secretary. cr oDOTHE AI EG1 SSPEECH.(previous reference:Cabinet 24(29) , Con-elusion 5. )PAKLTaME NTARYPROGRAMME.1. The Cabinet agreed - (a) To meet on FRIDAY tISXT, JUiE 28th,at 10--50 a.5u "vflVE^he followingp rineipa T"od"j e ct s: -(i) The final review of the King'sSpeech:(ii) To arrange the business ofParliament before the Recess.(b) That Ministers who are concernedwith legislation which:must be passed before the ParliamentaryRecess should place their Depart-ments in touch with the Treasurywith a view to agreement on thefinancial aspects of policy, andhave the necessary legislationdrafted with a view to' examination by the Committee of Home affairs at the earliest possible date:(c) That Ministers who have any points that they would like the PrimeMinister to refer to in his speech on the Address should communicate them to him not later than the evening of THURSDAY, JUliS 27th. E Q2.. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the President of the Board of Trade (paper cp.-166 (29)) relative to the question of theAustralian Tariff Preference. In this memorandum it was pointed out that in a reoent speech thePrime Minister of the Commonwealth of Australiahad intimated that in his opinion it should bepossible to stimulate the trade of this country with Australia by alterations in the AustralianPreferential Tariff system, and that he was anxious to approach the matter in a spirit ofco-operation. The British Prime Minister had at once expressed to Mr Bruce the Government1sappreciation of his attitude in a telegram a copyof which was attached to Paper CP.-166 (29).The Cabinet agreed To approve the proposal of thePresident of the Board of trade that he should take an early opportunity of referring to thematter in . public, "and that other Ministers should also bearit in mind in connection with anyspeeches they may be making in thenear future. Ig^SGUARDljSG- 3. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum[dp INDUSTRIES.1 by the President of the Board of Trade (Paperl(Previous C. P. -172 (29)) containing the draft of anI Reference:I Cabinet 23 announcement of policy re sardine; the Safeguardingj (29), Con-1 elusion 7.) of Industries, together with an alternativedraft suggested by the Chancellor of the Exchequer.The Cabinet agreed (a) To approve the proposal of thePresident of the Board of Tradein regard to the Report of theCorn) nit tee appointed to considerthe application of the SafeguardingDuty in respect of Woollen and worsted. Tissues, viz., that theReport should be published withoutdelay and that an announcement should be made in Parliament thatthe Government do not propose toask Parliament to impose a Dutyon these goods:(b) That Parliament should he informedthat the Government will not beprepared to receive any furtherapplications for Safeguarding Duties:Cc) To. reserve for further consideration at the next Meeting of the Cabinetthe question of the announcement tobe made in regard to the existingSafeguarding Duties:(d) That no announcement should be madeof the above decisions until theofficial statement has been madein Parliament.si THE COTTONINDUSTRY.The LabourSituationin.(previous reference:Cabinet 22(29), Con-conclusion 2.)3.A. In the course of the discussion onSafeguarding, the Cabinet took note of a Memo-randum by the Minister of Labour (Paper CP.-168(29)) reporting that the Federation of MasterCotton Spinners and the Cotton Spinners1 and manufacturers' Association have given notice ofa wages reduction of 25 per oent. on piece prices,with particulars of the negotiations in prospect.-3A- GERMANY-Reparations.(previous reference:Cabinet 22(29), Con-clusion 9.)4- With, reference to the Conclusion noted inthe margin, the Cabinet had before them thefollowing documents relative to the presentposition of the Reparations question:-The Report of the Committee of. Experts (Paper CP.-167 (29)):Summaries of the events prior tothe presentation of the Reportof the "Young" Committee and also of that Report itself (Paper CP.-174 (29)):A Memorandum by the Chancellor ofthe Exchequer (Paper CP.-175 (29)).The Cabinet took note of the desire of theChancellor of the Exchequer that they should makea close study of CP. Papers 174 and 175, and moreparticularly the Annex on page 6 of the latterentitled "Exposure of Italian Pretensions", and decided that the question should be discussed ata Meeting of the Cabinet on Friday, Jane 28th. THE BRITISHGOAL INDUSTRY.(previous references:Cabinet 60(27), Con-conclusion 1,and cabinet 2(29) , Con-clusion 6.)5. The Cabinet took note of the requestof the President of the Board of Trade that theyshould study carefully his Memorandum on theBritish Coal Industry (Paper CP.-176 (29)), and agreed That the Ministers to assist thePrime Minister in receivingrepresentatives of the Miners1 .Federation on Thursday, June 27th,at 2-30 p.im , should be :-The Lord Privy Seal,The President of the board ofTrade, with the Secretaryfor Mine s,The Minister of Labour. THE LONDONTRAFFIC 00-CEDINATIOhBILLS.(previous reference:Cabinet 6(29), Con-clusion 4. )6, The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Minister oi Transport (Paper CP.-170(29)) on the subject of the London Traffic(Co-ordinaiion) Bills, which, under the procedureapproved last Session, will, if the promotersdecide to proceed further, be carried automaticallyagain through their earlier stages In the Houseof Commons and come up again for Third Reading.With a view to avoiding further debate in theHouse of Commons at this stage the Minister pro-posed at an early date to have a confidential butfrank talk with Lord Ashfield, and asked for authority to suggest to him that he would be well advised not to attempt to proceed further withhis Bill and that no useful purpose would be served by forcing" upon the Government the necessityfor an express decision, which must be adverse.If asked what was the attitude of the Government,the Minister proposed to reply that he would beready at an early date to explore with LordAshfield and the other important interests con-cerned the best means of resuming considerationof a problem which he recognised to be urgent.The Cabinet agreed That -The Prime Minister,The Lord Privy Seal,The Minister of Transport,should confer on the subject and see Lord Ashfield if they thoughtadvisable. THE ELECTRICITY 7. The Cabinet had before them a MemorandumBOARD, . / \n-r by the Minister of Transport (Paper CP.-177 (29))The BatterseaGenerating on the subject of the Battersea Power Station,Station.containing the following recommendations:-(previous reference:Cabinet 17(29), Con-elusion 11. )(i) With regard to the Battersea general-ing Station I suggest that theGovernment experts concerned shouldbe asked to report as soon aspossible after they have been giventhe necessary data by the power company. It must be recognised thatin the meantime the Company is pro-oeeding with its works. It seemsnecessary to bear in mind in thisconnection that if any specialobligations were to be imposed onthe owners of the station with regardto the emission of smoke or fumes orthe creation of nuisances, the general question would be raised whether sachobligations ought not to be imposed on other electricity owners in similar circumstances, and even onall undertakings whose operationsmight cause effects of this kind inmore or less degree.(ii) That the Minister of Health, theFirst Commissioner of Works and myself should help in consultation on the various aspects of the question and watch it closely.(iii) With regard to the proposed extensionof the St. Marylebone generating station, I suggest that I may beauthorised to "inform the ElectricityCommissioners that I do not dissent from their proposal to authorise anextension of this Station subject tothe condition to which I hwve referred.The Cabinet agreed (a) That -The Minister of health the First Commissioner of works the Minister of Transport,should keep in close consultation onthe various aspects of the question and watch it closely:(b) That with regard to the St. MaryleboneGenerating Station the policy shouldbe as suggested in.(iii; above, andthat if there were any question ofthe Departmental responsibility for taking action it should be arranged by the three Ministers referred toin (a) above. THE HOUSINGSUBSIDY.(previous reference:Cabinet 23(29), Con-elusion 6.)8. The Cabinet had before them the following memoranda:-The Memorandum which had been circulated before the previous meeting of the Cabinet (paper c.P. -157 (29)), in which theMinister of Health asked authorityto proceed on the following lines:-(i) That in order to encourageLocal Authorities to proceeduninterruptedly with thedevelopment of their housing programme, and in order toavoid a discontinuity inthe amount of Local Authoritybuilding after October next,a very short Bill should beintroduced very early afterthe assembly of parliament and passed through all its stages before the Autumn,providing that the Order ofDecember last shall be of no effect so far as it deals withsubsidies under the Act of1924. The practical effectof this would be that the subsidies under the 1924 Actwould for the present remain unaltered:(ii) That the subsidy under the1923 Act, which goes prac-tioally entirely to privateenterprise building, shouldbe allowed to disappear, as provided for in the Order oflast December.A second Memorandum (Paper CP.-178(29)), in supplement of CP.-157 (29)containing statistics both as tothe fall in the numbers of subsidisedhouses due to the revision of theSubsidy, as well as the effect onunemployment, and urging; that it is extremely desirable to take stepsat once to reverse the decision ofthe late Government so far as it affects houses provided by LocalAuthor it ies.A Memorandum by the Secretary ofState lor Scotland on the same subject (Paper CP.-163 (29)). The Cabinet took note that the Ministerof Health and the Chancellor of the Exchequerwere agreed on the details of the policy proposed,and that the Minister of Health was having a Billprepared for consideration by the committee ofHome AffairsWhitehall Gardens, S.W.1,June 26, 1929. (iffTfLpOCUMJiHT IS THE PROPERTY Og HIS BriI5?aj:.'mO MiJ^TY'o GOYERNMx^T)S E C a B copy So._k_CAB I g E T 24 (29),Meeting of the Cabinet to be held at No- 10,Downing Street, S.W.1, on WEDNESDAY,June 26th, 1929, at 11.0 a-m-"CORRIGENDA TO AGENDA.1, Item 2. THE KING1 S SPEECH OH THE OPENING Off PARLIAMENT.Add the following Paper:-Memorandum by the President of theBoard of Education on Raising the school leaving Age to Fifteen.(CP. 173 (29 ) - Circulated herewith).2. The following will become Item 10;-THE BRITISH COAL INDUSTRY.Memorandum by the President of theBoard of Trade.(CP. 176 (29) - Already circulated).Items 10 to 12 on the Revised Agenda will inconsequence be re-numbered Nos. 11 to 13.(Signed) M.P.A. HaNKEY,Secretary to the Cabinet.2 Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1,25th June. 1929.
